title: 106_hr2651
content: The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999, also known as the Act, eliminates restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. It includes exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, changes in the definition of group practice, and delays in implementing ownership referral changes until final regulations are promulgated. Additionally, it excludes intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses, permits supervision of clinical laboratory services by independent contractor pathologists, and specifies an effective date. The Social Security Act is amended to clarify ownership or investment interests in entities through equity, with exceptions outlined in subsection (c). Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Act, including changes to ownership and compensation arrangement prohibitions, exceptions for ownership or investment interests in publicly traded securities and mutual funds, and adjustments to paragraph references. The Social Security Act is amended to clarify ownership or investment interests in entities through equity, with exceptions outlined in subsection (c). Amendments include redesignating paragraphs, striking subsections, and adjusting ownership and compensation arrangement prohibitions. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve removing specific clauses and restructuring rules for faculty ownership and investment interests in entities. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions. Revisions to the Social Security Act involve changes to the exception for in-office ancillary services, including the repeal of the site-of-service requirement and the definition of general supervision for physicians. The text discusses amendments to the Social Security Act related to licensure and certification requirements for physicians, clarification of treatment of physician owners of group practices, and a clarification of the exception for services furnished in a rural area. SEC. 4 amends the definition of group practice under the Social Security Act, specifying that a physician is considered a 'member' of a group if they are an owner or employee of the group. SEC. 5 delays the implementation of ownership referral changes until final regulations are promulgated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to exclude intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 7 allows pathologists who supervise clinical laboratory services for a group practice to be deemed members of the group. SEC. 8 states that the amendments apply to referrals made after the enactment date, regardless of regulations.
